ol.li: Understand the equivalence between a system of linear equations and a vector equation.
Learn the definition of \Span\{x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_k\}, and how to draw pictures of spans.
Pictures: an inconsistent system of equations, a consistent system of equations, spans in \R^2 and \R^3.

subsection.title: Vector Equations

statement.p: A vector equation is an equation involving a linear combination of vectors with possibly unknown coefficients.

bluebox.p: Asking whether or not a vector equation has a solution is the same as asking if a given vector is a linear combination of some other given vectors.

subsection.p: For example the vector equation above is asking if the vector (8,16,3) is a linear combination of the vectors (1,2,6) and (-1,2,-1).

statement.p: Consider the vector equation x\vec{1 1 1 2} + y \vec{0 1 1 0} + z \vec{0 0 1 -1} = \vec{3 -2 4 0}. Can you find all solutions to this equation? That is, all possible values for numbers x, y, z that make the equation true?

solution.p: The vector equation is the same as \vec{x x+y x+y+z 2x-z} = \vec{3 -2 4 0}. We can rewrite the vector equation as four equations that each must be true at the same time: x = 3, \qquad x+y=-2, \qquad x+y+z = 4, \qquad 2x-z=0. So we deduce that x=3 must be true from the first equation, then y= -2 -3 = -5 from the second and so z=4-3+5=6 from the third. The values x = 3,\, y=-5,\, z=6 make the fourth equation work out as well. There is a unique solution: x = 3,\, y=-5,\, z=6.
We can also use vector notation to write this solution as \vec{x y z} = \vec{3 -5 6}.

statement.p: Consider the vector equation x\vec{1 1 1} + y \vec{0 -1 -1} + z \vec{2 0 0} = \vec{3 1 1}. Does this vector equation have a solution? Does it have more than one solution?

solution.p: This vector equation has infinitely many solutions. We will solve equations like this more systematically later. For now, let's content ourselves with the observation that no matter what value of z we choose, setting x=3-2z and y=2-2z yields a solution, because (3-2z) \vec{1 1 1} + ( 2-2z) \vec{0 -1 -1} + z \vec{2 0 0} = \vec{3-2z+2z 3-2z-(2-2z) 3-2z-(2-2z)} = \vec{3 1 1}
For now, this might look a bit like magic. But you can try for yourself what happens if you set z=0, x=3 and y=2 or z=1, x=1 and y=0.

specialcase.p: Consider the vector equation x\vec{1 1 1} + y \vec{0 -1 -1} + z \vec{2 0 0} = \vec{1 3 1}. Does this vector equation have a solution? Does it have more than one solution?

This vector equation does not have any solution. We could write it as three separate equations: x+2z=1, \qquad x-y=3, \qquad x-y=1, which all have to be true at the same time for a solution x, y, z. The second equation says x-y=3 and the third says x-y=1. These two statements cannot be true at the same time, no matter what values of x and y we choose. So there can be no solution to the vector equation.

statement.p: If one or more solutions exist for an equation or a system of equations, it is said to be consistent. If an equation or system of equations does not have any solution, it is said to be inconsistent.

subsection.p: The above is the first of several essential definitions that we will see in this textbook. They are essential in that they form the essence of the subject of linear algebra: learning linear algebra means (in part) learning these definitions. All of the definitions are important, but it is essential that you learn and understand the definitions marked as such.

subsection.title: Spans
subsection.p: It will be useful to know what are all linear combinations of a set of vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k in \R^n. In other words, we would like to understand the set of all vectors b in \R^n such that the vector equation (in the unknowns x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_k) x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k = b has a solution (i.e. is consistent).

statement.p: Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k be vectors in \R^n. The span of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k is the collection of all linear combinations of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k, and is denoted \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\}. In symbols: \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\}Span of vectors \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} = \bigl\{x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k \mid x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_k \text{ in }\R\bigr\} We also say that \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is the subset spanned by or generated by the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k.

note.title: Set Builder Notation
note.p: You should read the notation \{x\mid\text{condition}\}Set builder notation \bigl\{x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k \mid x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_k \text{ in }\R\bigr\} as: the set of all things of the form x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k such that x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_k are in \R. The vertical line is such that; everything to the left of it is the set of all things of this form, and everything to the right is the condition that those things must satisfy to be in the set. Specifying a set in this way is called set builder notation.
All mathematical notation is only shorthand: any sequence of symbols must translate into an ordinary sentence.

note.title: Consistency and span
note.p:
Here are two ways of saying the same thing:
A vector b is in the span of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k.
The vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k = b is consistent, i.e., it has at least one solution.

Later, in we will develop a procedure for answering the question “is b in the span of v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k?” in every circumstance. This will be a byproduct of developing a process to find all the solutions of vector equations.

figure.caption: This is a picture of an inconsistent linear system: the vector w on the right-hand side of the equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 = w is not in the span of v_1,v_2. Convince yourself of this by trying to solve the equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 = w by moving the sliders, and by row reduction. Compare this .

solution.p: This question is asking whether we can find scalars x_1 and x_2 that make the equation \vec{3 1 1} = x_1\vec{1 0 0} + x_2\vec{1 1 1} hold. We can rearrange this to give \vec{3 1 1} = \vec{x_1+x_2 0+x_2 0+x_2}, which we can rewrite this vector equation as three ordinary equations \syseq{x_1+x_2=3; x_2=1; x_2=1\rlap.} If we set x_1=2 and x_2=1, then the equations are true. Therefore we can write \vec{3 1 1} = 2 \vec{1 0 0} + \vec{1 1 1}. This shows that \vec{3 1 1} is in \Span\left\{ \vec{1 0 0}, \vec{0 1 1} \right\}.

This question is very similar to the last one. Can find scalars x_1 and x_2 that make the equation \vec{3 1 0} = x_1\vec{1 0 0} + x_2\vec{1 1 1} hold. We can rearrange this to give \vec{3 1 0} = \vec{x_1+x_2 0+x_2 0+x_2}, which we can rewrite this vector equation as three ordinary equations \syseq{x_1+x_2=3; x_2=1; x_2=0\rlap.} The last two equations here contradict each other. They cannot both be true at the same time. This shows that \vec{3 1 0} is not in \Span\left\{ \vec{1 0 0}, \vec{0 1 1} \right\}.

paragraphs.title: Pictures of Spans
paragraphs.p: Drawing a picture of \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is the same as drawing a picture of all linear combinations of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k.

figure.caption: Pictures of spans in \R^3. The span of two noncollinear vectors is the plane containing the origin and the heads of the vectors. Note that three coplanar (but not collinear) vectors span a plane and not a 3-space, just as two collinear vectors span a line and not a plane.
